body_text.text: www.aaojournal.org). The overall incidence of sCOVID-19 among eye professionals 89 across 10 hospitals was 2.52% (95% Confidence Interval (CI): 1.68-3.63%). The 90

incidence of COVID-19 in ophthalmologists was similar to that seen in ophthalmic 91 nurses and technicians ( to the control group, case subjects were older (P=0.01), had been in practice longer 100 (P=0.001), had higher rates of contact with confirmed or suspected COVID-19 101 patients (P=0.002), reported higher rates of lack of sleep (P=0.008), and lack of PPE 102 supply (P=0.02) before January 20, 2020 when the Chinese government confirmed 103 human-to-human transmission ( Table 1B) . Both groups showed a significant increase 104 in PPE use after January 20 (all P<0.0001, Table 3 , available at www.aaojournal.org). 105

In addition, control subjects more frequently avoided direct skin contact with patients 106 by using gloves or cotton tips (P=0.03). 107 108 Generally, ophthalmologists may have been considered to be a low-risk subspecialty 109 in the pandemic; however, our data showed at least a similar risk of sCOVID-19 110 among eye professionals when compared to healthcare workers in general in Wuhan. concern in studies based on questionnaire data, with a risk of affected individuals 139 over-reporting symptoms and inadequate PPE and hand hygiene. The dates during which COVID-19 was diagnosed for the 28 case subjects are listed along the timeline. The horizontal axis includes the dates between January 10, 2020 and March 5, 2020. Two key time points were marked: A, January 20, 2020 when the Chinese government first announced human-to-human transmission; B, January 23, 2020 when Wuhan was locked down by government mandate. Each subject is represented by a vertical line represents marked with a case number. Ophthalmologists, ophthalmic nurses, and ophthalmic technicians were labeled black, red, and blue, respectively. The length of each vertical line indicates disease severity: short, mild disease; medium; severe disease; long, death. The majority of cases (85.7%) were diagnosed between the middle of January and early February. Figure 1B . The geographic locations of 10 hospitals where eye professionals contracted COVID-19. The hospitals were labeled A through J and marked as red circles. The radius of each circle is proportional to the incidence of COVID-19 among eye professionals in each hospital; higher incidence corresponding with a larger circle. The Huanan Seafood market, the believed origin of Wuhan COVID-19 epidemic, is also labeled in the map. The hospitals with the highest incidences (hospitals E and G) were clustered within 4.5 kilometer of the Huanan Seafood market. Although hospital B, a small eye institution located in proximity to this market, had a much lower incidence than hospitals E and G, hospital E's incidence was still higher than a similarly-sized eye institution more distant from the market (hospital C).

FIGREF0.text: developed severe disease including 3 deaths. All 3 deaths were ophthalmologists 79 who had worked in the same hospital. Due to the relatively low positive rate of 80 RT-PCR in patients with COVID-19 early in the epidemic in Wuhan, serum antibody 81 tests were also used to diagnose COVID-19. Except for two patients who died prior to 82 receiving serum antibody testing, all cases with negative RT-PCR tested positive for 83 SARS-CoV-2 antibody. Only 5 cases (17.9%) had family members with sCOVID-19.

FIGREF2.text: 111Extrapolated from data available from the Wuhan Red Cross Foundation and Wuhan 112 Health Commission, 3,4 we estimated that the overall COVID-19 incidence among all 113 healthcare workers in the 10 hospitals was 2.27% (713 contracted health workers out 114 of 31,367). 115116The incidence of sCOVID-19 and associated severe cases or death peaked during 117 the early phase of the pandemic and decreased significantly two weeks after the 118 mandated lock-down, consistent with the incidence curve of sCOVID-19 among 119 healthcare workers in Wuhan.5 During city lock-down, only urgent patients were seen 120 in eye clinics, leading to less SARS-CoV-2 exposure for eye professionals. Thisobserved clustering effect appears to support the effectiveness of stopping 122 transmission and controlling disease spread. 123 124 Given the risk of COVID-19 among the eye professionals, PPE use is highly 125 recommended. After using PPE, even near the epicenter of the epidemic, there were 126 only 2 new sCOVID-19 cases in hospitals E and G (those closest to the origin of the 127 epidemic) compared to 9 cases before using PPE. Older age, lack of PPE, lack of 128 sufficient sleep, and less diligent hand hygiene were the risk factors for sCOVID-19 129 contraction in this study. 130 131 Our study has several limitations. First, providers with sCOVID-19 were identified 132 through contact with Key Informants. Ascertainment bias can inflate the proportion of 133 severe cases by missing those asymptomatic or mildly symptomatic cases. Thus, 134 results from this study only applied to symptomatic COVID-19 among eye 135 professionals. Second, although controls had negative RT-PCR tests, SARS-CoV-2 136 antibody tests were not performed; as such, we cannot rule out the possibility of 137 asymptomatic COVID-19 among controls. In addition, recall bias is an important 138

FIGREF3.text: , this study reported incidence of symptomatic COVID-19 among eye 142 professionals in Wuhan China and demonstrated that decrease in patient volume with 143 city lock-down, adequate PPE, and diligent hand hygiene are important in preventing 144 disease transmission. 145

FIGREF4.text: The time course of eye professionals with COVID-19 in Wuhan and the geographic distribution of affiliated hospitals

TABREF0.text: Chinese Medicine, Hubei institute of Chinese medicine, Hubei Province, China acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus 2 (SARS-CoV-2), has had global impact. 1 48 Eye professionals may be at risk for contracting COVID-19 as face-to-face proximity 49 is required to examine patients using a slit lamp or ophthalmoscope. 50Here, we conducted a cross-sectional case-control questionnaire survey in the 52 hospitals that had eye professionals with symptomatic COVID-19 (sCOVID-19) in 53 Wuhan, where the infection first emerged. The goal of this study was to understand 54 the incidence of sCOVID-19 among eye professionals and to improve their safety as 55The survey was conducted from February 26 to March 20, 2020. Using the Key 58Informant Method,we received a list of eye professionals with sCOVID-19 diagnosed 59 through February 29, 2020 from the Wuhan Ophthalmology Society. This list was 60 confirmed by the chairman of each respective ophthalmology department. Cases 61 were diagnosed and disease severity was graded by treating pulmonologists based 62 on the latest diagnostic criteria. 2 Control subjects were randomly selected within each 63 ophthalmology department where case(s) were identified using 3-4 controls per case. 64 All participants were ophthalmologists, ophthalmic nurses, or technicians who worked 65 in an ophthalmology department and had been involved in patient care since the 66 outbreak. The questionnaire, distributed to the participants through a link built into the 67 WeChat program (Tencent Technology Co. Ltd，Shenzhen, China), included 68 demographic information and information on personal protective equipment (PPE) 69 and hand hygiene. After informed consent was obtained, all questionnaires were 70 answered by the participants themselves with the exception of 2 participants: one who passed away, and another who remained intubated through data collection. The 72 study was conducted in accordance with the Declaration of Helsinki and approved by 73 the Institutional Review Board of Central Theater Command General Hospital. 74

The two hospitals 92 with the highest incidences (hospitals E and G) were tertiary referral centers clustered 93 within 4.5 kilometer to the Huanan Seafood market, the believed origin of the 94 COVID-19 pandemic(Figure 1B, available at www.aaojournal.org).All controls had no symptoms with negative RT-PCR testing. Both case and control 97 groups had similar sex distribution, ratio of ophthalmologists to ophthalmic staff, 98 working environments, and PPE training for COVID-19 (P>0.05). However, compared 99
